content.html:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. Find the value of each of the arithmetic sequences below. Enter your answers as an integer only. . Do not include commas or periods.
    1. Find the \(21^{st}\) term of a sequence where the first term is \(3\) and the common difference is \(8\).
      Enter your answer here:

Correct! 163

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 4.17.2 and 4.17.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(163\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Find the \(30^{th}\) term of a sequence where the first term is \(–14\) and the common difference is \(5\).
      Enter your answer here:

Correct! \(131\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 4.17.2 and 4.17.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(131\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Find the \(16^{th}\) term of a sequence where the first term is \(11\) and the common difference is \(–6\).
      Enter your answer here:

Correct! –79

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 4.17.2 and 4.17.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(–79\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Find the value of each of the geometric sequences below. Do not use commas or spaces in your answers. Enter your answer as integers only. . Do not include commas or periods.
    1. Find the \(11^{th}\) term given the first term is \(8\) and the common ratio is \(3\).
      Enter your answer here:

Correct! \(472392\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 4.17.2–4.17.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(472392\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Find the \(10^{th}\) term given the first term is \(–6\) and the common ratio is \(–2\).
      Enter your answer here:

Correct! 3072

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 4.17.2–4.17.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(3072\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. A sequence is defined recursively by \(f_1=-6, f_n=f_{n-1}-2\), for \(n≥2\). Which of the following gives the nth term for \(n≥0\)?

Correct! \(a_{n}=-6+(n-1)(-2) \)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 4.17.2–4.17.5. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(a_{n}=-6+(n-1)(-2) \). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. A sequence is defined recursively by \(f_1=-20, f_n=f_{(n-1)}+5\) for \(n≥2\). Which of the following is the nth term?

Correct! \(a_{n}=-20+(n-1)(5)\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 4.17.2–4.17.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(a_{n}=-20+(n-1)(5)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. A sequence is defined recursively by \(f_1=3\), \(f_n=2 \cdot f_{n-1}\), \(n\geq2\). Which of the following gives the nth term for \(n\geq0\)?

Correct! \(f_n=3 \cdot 2^{n-1}\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 4.17.2–4.17.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(f_n=3 \cdot 2^{n-1}\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. A sequence of numbers is given by \(a_2=1\), \(a_3=5\), \(a_4=9\), \(a_5=13\), \(a_6=17\). Which equation can be used to find the nth term of the sequence?

Correct! \(4n-7\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 4.17.2–4.17.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(4n-7\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?
